author: Eyad (CTown)
message:
Nice, these shortcuts seem very consistent. I feel these shortcuts fit in well with the recent initiatives to make Plasma all around consistent.

Also, would that leave "ctrl" (and "ctrl+shift") for applications only?

replies.author: Aur√©lien G√¢teau
replies.message: Yes, my idea is that all global shortcuts must use the Win modifier and apps must not. This reduces the conflict risks.

author: lemondawn
message:
I have a heavy-keyboard setup as well, although quite different to yours:
win+left - move window to left (on the same desktop); same for other arrows
win+home/end - tile window on the left/right half
win+insert/delete/pageup/pagedn - tile window on the 1/4 of the screen topleft/bottomleft/...
win+space/m - maximize/minimize
win+number - switch to a VD
win+alt+number - move current window to a VD

author: Bugreporter
message:
I have created a shortcut to search for the currently selected/clipboad text in the pubmed databse (scientific literature database). The command string is:

> firefox "http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov...`qdbus org.kde.klipper /klipper getClipboardContents`"

This is very handy and worked very well for me. It should work with any other search engine/URL, too.

author: DanaKil
message:
"There is a logical link between a shortcut and its meaning. For example, the shortcut to maximize a window is Win + M"
This is not a new problem but this only works with language for which the action begins with a "M" of course. Do you thinks that shortcuts must be localized or is this even possible ?

Otherwise, I like your shortcuts. Maybe you could export your settings so that other people can play with this new set ?

And the first and only keyboard shortcut change I really need for each new KDE install is "ctrl+space" for KRunner but your "win+space" fits perfectly my needs too.

replies.author: Aur√©lien G√¢teau
replies.message: Indeed, M for Maximize does not work for all languages, but I don't think it's a good idea to localize shortcuts, as it would means retraining when you use a computer set up for another language and it would make it harder for developers to choose shortcuts. With this in mind, maybe GNOME shortcuts (Win + Left: maximize left, Win + Up: maximize, Win + Right, maximize right) are more universal.

replies.author: Jos Poortvliet
replies.message: Yes, those are very logical and simple, I use them too...

author: Sudhir Khanger
message:
Plasma has a very weird Keyboard setting. Application Keyboard Shortcuts are in fact global as they work across applications. And Global Keyboard shortcuts are for individual applications. I don't know why that it.

Something like should be adopted by Plasma and applications.

replies.author: Jos Poortvliet
replies.message:
The application keyboard shortcuts configure the keyboard behaviour *in* applications, hence the name. The global ones act global - no matter what application you are in, but various workspace components have them so you have to switch between them to configure them. I am not saying it is great logic, just saying there is some üòé

Yes, it can use some work...

replies.author: Sudhir Khanger
replies.message: Not going to happen until Wayland. I read the mailing list discussion about using Meta keys as a trigger for KRunner which current Plasma doesn't support and developer point of view was that X11 just doesn't have a novel solution for this problem.

replies.author: Aur√©lien G√¢teau
replies.message: If I am not mistaken, Wayland is needed to be able to use Meta as a plain key instead of a modifier, so that you can press Meta alone and trigger something. Wayland is not needed to be able to use Meta as a modifier for Plasma global shortcuts.

author: Heiko Tietze
message: It makes sense to combine meta with window management, absolutely. But in case of meta+tab to switch between windows, I would miss the trilogy with alt+tab and ctrl+tab (mdi/tab switch). And how to toggle through activities? (perhaps AltGr+Tab *g*)

replies.author: Aur√©lien G√¢teau
replies.message: Regarding activities, I wonder if there really is a need for keyboard shortcuts to switch between them: if you have, say, a work and a home activity, switching from one to the other is not something you do so often that it requires shortcuts. Maybe a Win + A shortcut to open the activity list would be good enough? I think the problem here is that not everybody uses activities the same way or with the same granularity.

replies.author: Jos Poortvliet
replies.message:
I agree. Also, most 'normal' people barely use virtual desktops - activities are ANOTHER layer of complexity, and badly supported in most apps anyway. Unless we simplify the concept, it isn't going to be used much...

(I would suggest to merge virtual desktops and activities, to make activities usable for >50% of our users, rather than the 0.1% today - but this will annoy the 0.001% who care about having BOTH Activities AND virtual desktops and as KDE usually optimizes for the 0.001%, I guess this won't happen. Too bad, Activities is a great thing in theory... Sorry for the passive aggressiveness but this is of course stupid and thus annoying me as I don't care about the 0.0001% but want KDE to be successful for the other 99.99%)

author: Jos Poortvliet
message: I have been using Win+arrows for tile left/right, maximize (up) and minimize (down). Very nice, logical. I also use the run x command dialog (dedicated key, if on keyboard, otherwise alt-f2) and alt-tab (switch app), ctrl-tab (switch desktop), f11 (fullscreen - binding in Kwin so it always works), f12 (yakuake), and last but not least ctrl-~ for klipper's menu (i use it a lot and this is a very easy, fast shortcut). Of course ctrl-c/x/v too.

replies.author: Aur√©lien G√¢teau
replies.message: I don't like globally binding F11 to fullscreen because it prevents applications from adjusting their user interface to a fullscreen mode (like Firefox or Gwenview do)

replies.author: Jos Poortvliet
replies.message:
Actually, it works just fine in Firefox and Chromium. It doesn't in Gwenview - perhaps that can be considered a bug ;-)

I guess FF detects if it is full screen and adjusts.

replies.author: Aur√©lien G√¢teau
replies.message: Oh interesting, I was not aware of that.

author: Gregor Mi
message:
Feels good. Some remarks:

1) Does it mean to abandon Alt+Tab (Alt+Shift+Tab) in favour of the Win key variant? Though I like the consistency of the scheme, I think the Alt+Tab combination is pretty settled and should at least also work.

2) I like Win+Esc as a much better alternative to Alt+F4. What about Win+Q for the small-handed to "quit" a window? Or Win+W (similar to Ctrl+W to close a tab, though I would not have associated the W with closing something and thus rule it out).

3) I also use Win+L to lock. And additionally Win+D to show the desktop. D for Desktop. ;-)

4) Thanks to your post I found out that Ctrl+Shift+F or Win+F switch fullscreen applications to non-fullscreen. I would find it consistent if Win+D also would work in fullscreen applications (exit fullscreen and show desktop). The Win+Tab (Alt+Tab) should also work there (which it currently does not).

replies.author: Aur√©lien G√¢teau
replies.message:
1) Those are just personal experiments, I do not plan to do any lobbying to get the defaults changed, though I think some of them make sense :)

2) I used Win+Q at first, but I always ended up being confused about whether I should use Ctrl or Win.

author: Jens Reuterberg
message:
Ah I got for the "Meta+" set up personally trying to make certain that I can access all shortcuts with my left hand only. So with windows I have Meta+Q as close, Meta+Z as "maximize", Meta+X as "Tile left", Meta+C for "Tile Right", Meta+V for "lower window" and Meta+B for "fullscreen".
Meta+A is "Show all desktops" and Meta+S is "Show all windows current desktop". I use Ksuperkey so I have Meta only as a way to start launcher, Meta+Space for Krunner and Alt+Space for Yakuake.
My plan is to change the Virtual Desktops shortcuts soonish so I can use that too with only the left hand.
